posts.name: Brandon Crofts
posts.cooked:
This is our first year employing swerve drive as a team (we use NEO Vortex Mk4i swerve modules, that contain a ThriftyBot absolute encoder). Every time we rebuild our code, we have to manually align our wheels to the forward position. We have a method in our SwerveModule class that resets the drive and turning positions of the (CANSpark) motor encoders to 0 and the absolute encoder’s offset, respectively. Is there a way to write code that instead automatically determines where the modules are and sets them to forward, then resets the turning encoders?

We are also having issues with slight drifting while we drive forward; I am unsure if this is related or not. Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Can you share your code? Did you start with a particular code template?

posts.name: Brandon Crofts
posts.cooked:

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
Could you post a link to a repo?

I am a bit confused on what you want to do.

It looks like you are reading the absolute encoder and seeing the value to your relative steering encoder. Assuming you have the scaling, direction, absolute offset and wrapping correct, once you tell the steer motors to drive forward they should align.

You wouldn’t need to reset the steering motor back to 0 once they are facing forward.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Where do you set absoluteEncoderOffsetRad ? If I had to guess, your issue is that you’re setting it incorrectly (it should be fixed for your drivebase).

Does the absolute encoder correctly change values as you spin the module (the raw value without the absoluteEncoderOffsetRad ), including when you power cycle?

CoachCrofts:

Every time we rebuild our code, we have to manually align our wheels to the forward position.

Does it only happen when you deploy new code, or does it also happen when you turn your robot off and on? What are the symptoms if you don’t align the wheels?

Full source code is really helpful in debugging problems like these (asking for programming help without code is a bit like asking a mechanic for car help without showing him your car).

posts.name: Brandon Crofts
posts.cooked:
Our district doesn’t allow us to use GitHub, so I don’t have a repo to share, unfortunately. (If we make one in the coming days, I’ll reply to this thread).

I agree that once we’ve set the wheels forward manually and set the turningEncoder’s values based on the offset, they generally do align. However, I was wondering if there was a way in which we could place our robot down on the field without manually aligning the wheels, and having code execute that would shift each of the four wheels into the forward direction at the start of, say, autonomous.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
CoachCrofts:

However, I was wondering if there was a way in which we could place our robot down on the field without manually aligning the wheels, and having code execute that would shift each of the four wheels into the forward direction

The code you sent in the picture should be capable of accomplishing that, if you’re calling it with the right parameters.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
It sounds like you either aren’t scaling the abs encoder values to the same domain as your relative (likely radians), or some directions are flipped ( clockwise vs ccw). Or the handling of where the wrapping from 0-2pi isn’t correct. Or the offsets from the absolute encoders to point to zero isn’t correct.

Could you maybe post the entire file you have a picture of on pastebin? That might be enough to help.

posts.name: Brandon Crofts
posts.cooked: Hey, I made a repo for the code, here it is: GitHub - BrandonCrofts/OceansideKraken2024

posts.name: Emilio Alvarez
posts.cooked:
Took a look at your repo. Have you confirmed that getAbsoluteEncoderRad in SwerveModule.java is returning a value that you expect?

Two additional notes that are possibly related:

You’ll want to call burnFlash after you make settings changes to a Rev device, to make sure that they hold their settings during power loss that does not include robot code reboot

If you are delaying robot sensor init with your thread in SwerverSubsytem.java ,  then you should also call the zero all encoders and reset your pose estimation at that point.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
I agree that getAbsoluteEncoderRad doesn’t look quite right if my assumptions on how your swerves are set up.

If you are setting one encoder value to another on the same shaft but they “pointing at each other” then cw for one is ccw to the other, not just the negative.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked:
Lyanthropos:

If you are delaying robot sensor init with your thread in SwerverSubsytem.java , then you should also call the zero all encoders and reset your pose estimation at that point.

This worked!

The other thing we had to fix was ensuring all of the absolute encoders were set to the same rotation direction in code.  The left were reversed from the rights, probably because I’m still thinking in tank drive.
